messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:45): http://digitaldaily.allthingsd.com/20100514/chuck-geschke-on-adobe-flash-apple/
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:46): Adobe co-chair comments on HTML standardization
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:50): Remember kids, proprietry is best!
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:51): """[...] you get the experience of HTML on the Web, where the kind of browser, hardware and OS you use determines what your experience"""
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:52): I take it he has never tried to use flash on mobile then
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:52): Unless he is claiming that consistent awfulness is a virtue?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (13:12): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: http://twitter.com/ronanklyne/statuses/14218178122
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (13:16): JP: Why isn‚Äôt Flash an open standard?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (13:16): CG: It is. What are you talking about?

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (13:16): "If you look at the amount of time it will take HTML5 to become a reasonably solid platform, it‚Äôs going to take a long time because there are an awful lot of vested interests trying to influence its development."
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (13:16): Thankfully, the editorial process at the WHATWG insures that vested interests can all jump off a bridge, unless they're held by browser implementers.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:22): that remains to be seen
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:23): since the WHATWG is pretty much deferring to the W3C
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:23): and it would take a pretty big vested interest to change that
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (13:24): So far the only deference to the W3C has been on basically editorial matters, or matters that pertain only to the W3C spec, no?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (13:25): Or things that are fairly unimportant.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:25): i was going to say the opposite
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:25): the only things that the whatwg has done differently is editorial things
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:25): e.g. spec organisation
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:26): but so far there haven't been any cases of decisions made by the w3c that are controversial and non-editorial
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (13:27): What I meant was that when the W3C has overruled the WHATWG (= you), it's been mostly editorial, and unimportant when not editorial.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:27): indeed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:27): so far
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:27): sleep time
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:27): nn
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (13:27): Good night.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:44): innerHTML is IE is far more brittle than I had thought
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (13:52): hmm, in gecko i get "<input type="disabled">" for innerHTML of <input disabled="">
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (13:52): i mean i get "<input disabled="disabled">"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:55): oops
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:18): "This is yet another proposal to replace <video>, <audio>, <model> etc with a single element: <include>." -- good times
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (14:19): God help us all
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (14:20): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: I'm not 100% sure that our innerHTML implementation uses the HTML5 parser yet
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (14:20): wait, I don't see edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e's quote
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:22): whatwg list
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:25): Must resist urge to suggest <element @role> to replace all other elements
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (14:26): hmm, my mail must be backlogged
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:29): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: Don't forget <attribute @role> to replace all other attributes
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (14:31): Should introduce <anything>
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:32): 58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 and ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c? Now that's just evil.
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (14:33): It would certainly be interesting to define parsing and display rules for <anything>
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (14:33): If the contents validate as an URL, fetch the content. Depending on the Content-Type header display a) a video, b) a music player, c) an iframe...
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:34): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: You don't like primes?
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (14:34): an <iframe> already does that
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:34): How about replacing the entire language with <html src="file.html">
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:35): That's not Semantic enough. We need <html src="file.rdf">
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:35): So that users can define their own tag ontologies
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:39): hrm. contentDocument.open() doesn't work on an iframe that's not in a document :-(

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:43): speaking of replacing attributes .. http://docs.google.com/Doc?docid=0AaYxrITemjbxZGNmZzc5cHpfM2Ryajc5Zmhx&hl=en .. <input type=speech> spec proposal also proposes adding "grammar" and "grammartype" attributes
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:43): we all remember how much we loved the word "grammar" in school
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:44): Quite a bit, but not as much as syntax?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:45): well, I never had a Syntax Book
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:45): but I did have a Grammar Book
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:45): which I did my best to abuse as much as possible
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:46): maybe it's just a kneejerk reaction, but I feel like any feature that'd require the use of a "grammar" attribute can't be a step in the right direction
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:49): the spec seems like a case of overengineering
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:49): or at least like way too much overloading of the input element
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:49): but the use cases do seem important
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:50): the uses cases being things like doing Web searches by voice, adding voice to turn-by-turn directions/navigations
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:51): an translation applications with voice
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:51): this just doesn't strike me at least as the most obviously optimal way to provide a feature for those use cases
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (14:52): It overlaps with <device> quite a bit
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:52): yeah, edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e asked about that on the list already, I think
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:53): Shouldn't such input be media-independent?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:09): wow. After making a demo that fails gracefully in IE8, I can understand the frustration Web authors have with IE
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:10): the way IE deals with absent properties on host objects is... annoying

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:14): could someone with IE9 Platform Preview tell me what happens when loading http:/ b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9.iki.fi/test/moz/detect-html5-parser.html please?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:24): I wonder if innerHTML malfunctions in IE8 when the node is not in the document...
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:27): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: iirc innerHTML works fine for nodes outside the document
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (15:29): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: will know in a couple of minutes, rebooting to windows 7
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (15:32): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: script error encountered
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (15:32): "Object expected" in detect-html5-parser.js on line 76
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:33): 58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354: what about on reload now (I changed line 76)

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:33): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: should we expose the subprotocol to script? a script can open a connection without asking for a subprotocol, but the server can reply with one (which the client ignores)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:34): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: for limited values of "fine", it appears
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (15:34): No problem!
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:35): better than IE8 but nowhere close to compliant
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:37): pointed to b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9's test in the ie9 bug he filed a few days ago
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:39): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: what's limited?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:39): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: innerHTML on <html> and <table> doesn't work in ie even when they're in the document
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:53): Hmm, how can I find out if all files in a folder are identical?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:54): If not, which ones differ from some reference?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:54): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: most tests in my demo never get as far as having a non-null e.firstChild in IE8
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:55): gets reminded of FILE DIR as arguments for diff
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:56): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: diff -r dir1 dir2
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:56): if you mean comparing two parallel directories
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:57): If you mean comparing all the files within a directory to each other, md5sum *|sort and then look for odd ones out
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:00): Next random question: is there any way to add a 5s delay to all requests to Apache httpd?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:01): How?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:03): shrugs
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:03): I guess you could use mod_perl and set a PerlPostReadRequestHandler that does "sleep 5" or something along those lines

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:05): (or copy-and-paste a proxy server example from some asynchronous networking framework and add a delay call into that, so that you don't tie up expensive Apache processes)
